taxPlanning.title: Tax Payment Extension Directive No. 142/2011
taxPlanning.excerpt: According to Proclamation No. 983/2008 on Tax Administration, a taxpayer who is unable to pay their tax debt in full or in one installment may request an extension of the payment period from the Ministry of Revenue.
taxPlanning.fullContent:
According to Proclamation No. 983/2008 on Tax Administration, a taxpayer who is unable to pay their tax debt on time or in one installment may request an extension of the payment period from the Ministry of Revenue.

Therefore, as clarified by the Ministry of Revenue, if a taxpayer is unable to pay their tax debt on time or in one installment, the Ministry may grant an extension of the payment period. This directive outlines the procedures for implementing this provision. It is appropriate to establish a fair and accountable system by entering into an extended payment agreement and ensuring proper procedures are followed.

The directive also details the conditions under which a tax payment extension may be granted or denied.

1. Conditions for Granting a Tax Payment Extension:
According to this directive, a tax payment extension agreement may be granted under the following conditions:
• The taxpayer is unable to pay their tax debt in one installment.
• The taxpayer is not at a high risk level when the tax assessment or tax calculation notice is issued.
• The taxpayer provides a bank guarantee equivalent to the debt if their assets are seized or auctioned.

2. Conditions for Denying a Tax Payment Extension:
According to Sub-Article 1 of Article 5 of this directive, a tax payment extension will not be granted under the following conditions:
• The tax debt is indirect tax or income tax to be deducted from the taxpayer's account.
• The taxpayer has previously been granted a payment extension but failed to pay the debt within the agreed period without a valid reason.
• The amount of tax debt requested for extension is subject to the taxpayer's compliance.

According to Sub-Article 2 of Article 5 of this directive, the taxpayer must receive a written notification from the tax authority within 30 days of submitting the extension request, indicating the decision.

Regarding the payment period and installment plan, if the taxpayer demonstrates that they are unable to pay due to reasons beyond their control, the extension may be granted for up to three months. However, if the taxpayer requests the same extension for three consecutive tax periods, the tax debt payment period will not be extended.

The directive also specifies how and when the tax debt payment period will be determined when a tax calculation notice is issued and an extension agreement is entered into.

- For high-level taxpayers, if the total principal tax, penalty, and interest debt ranges from 750,000 to 2.5 million Birr, the payment period may be extended for up to six months. For debts between 2.5 million and 3.75 million Birr, the extension may be up to eight months. For debts between 3.75 million and 5 million Birr, the extension may be up to ten months, and for debts above 5 million Birr, the extension may be up to twelve months.
- For medium-level taxpayers, if the total principal tax, penalty, and interest debt ranges from 50,000 to 125,000 Birr, the payment period may be extended for up to three months. For debts between 125,000 and 750,000 Birr, the extension may be up to eight months. For debts between 2.5 million and 3.75 million Birr, the extension may be up to ten months, and for debts above 3.75 million Birr, the extension may be up to twelve months.
- For small taxpayers, if the total principal tax, penalty, and interest debt ranges from 5,000 to 12,500 Birr, the payment period may be extended for up to three months. For debts between 12,501 and 75,000 Birr, the extension may be up to six months. For debts between 75,001 and 250,000 Birr, the extension may be up to eight months. For debts between 250,001 and 750,000 Birr, the extension may be up to ten months, and for debts above 750,000 Birr, the extension may be up to twelve months.
- For micro taxpayers, if the total principal tax, penalty, and interest debt ranges from 1,000 to 10,000 Birr, the payment period may be extended for up to three months. For debts between 10,000 and 20,000 Birr, the extension may be up to six months. For debts between 20,000 and 40,000 Birr, the extension may be up to eight months. For debts between 40,001 and 60,000 Birr, the extension may be up to ten months, and for debts above 60,001 Birr, the extension may be up to twelve months.

This directive also outlines the procedures for submitting extension requests and the conditions that must be met:
- A taxpayer requesting a tax payment extension must pay at least 25% of the tax debt as a down payment.
- If the taxpayer's assets have been seized, they must pay the costs incurred by the tax authority and at least 25% of the tax debt as a down payment. The seizure may only be lifted if the taxpayer provides a bank guarantee equivalent to the debt.
- If the taxpayer disagrees with the tax decision notice, they may file a complaint with the Tax Appeal Division or the Tax Appeal Commission. The tax paid during the appeal process will be credited toward the down payment and the remaining debt.
- This directive also provides additional explanations and procedures for special cases where a tax payment extension may be granted.

In special cases, extension requests must be submitted to the branch office, which will forward the request along with the taxpayer's payment history and reasons for the extension to the Tax Debt Administration Directorate. The Directorate will then submit the decision to the Minister or their representative, who may reduce the down payment to 15% based on the taxpayer's financial situation. This process also applies to the revenue authorities of Addis Ababa and Dire Dawa.

This directive provides detailed provisions on the tax payment extension process and its implementation based on the taxpayer's circumstances.

auditPreparation.title: Rental Income Tax
auditPreparation.excerpt: Taxable rental income refers to the income a taxpayer earns from renting out property during the fiscal year after deducting allowable expenses.
auditPreparation.fullContent:
1. Taxable Rental Income
Taxable rental income refers to the income a taxpayer earns from renting out property during the fiscal year after deducting allowable expenses.
Gross rental income includes the following:
- Rent payments or similar payments received by the taxpayer during the fiscal year as per the rental agreement,
- Payments made by the tenant on behalf of the landlord during the fiscal year,
- Any bond, guarantee, or similar amount held by the taxpayer for damages that were not used during the fiscal year,
- Amounts spent by the tenant for repairs or improvements to the property as per the rental agreement,
- Gross income earned by the taxpayer when renting out property along with goods, which also includes rental income from the goods.

2. Sublessors
Taxable income for a sublessor refers to the income earned by the sublessor during the fiscal year after deducting the rent paid to the main landlord and other expenses incurred to earn the income.
If a sublessor allows the tenant to sublet the property without paying tax, the sublessor will be responsible for paying the tax.

3. Notification of New Rental Property
A contractor or property owner must notify the local administration or district administration of the name, address, and taxpayer identification number (TIN) of the person liable to pay tax on the rental income if the property is completed or rented out.
The local administration or district administration must provide this information to the tax authority.

4. Rental Income Tax Rates
The rental income tax rate for organizations is 30%.
For individuals, the rental income tax rates are as follows:

5. Deductible Expenses
For taxpayers not required to maintain accounting records, the following expenses are deductible when calculating taxable rental income:
- Payments made to the government or city administration during the fiscal year for land or property-related taxes (excluding income tax),
- 50% of the gross income from renting out furniture and equipment for storage, accommodation, or replacement,
- The above 50% deduction does not apply to taxpayers required to maintain accounting records.
For taxpayers required to maintain accounting records, necessary expenses incurred to earn the income are deductible, including:
- Land lease payments,
- Maintenance costs, depreciation of the property, furniture, and equipment,
- Interest and carbon taxes,
- Payments made to the government or city administration for land or property-related taxes (excluding income tax).

6. Rental Losses
Provisions for carrying forward rental losses for business income tax purposes also apply to rental income tax.

7. Rental Payments Covering More Than One Year
If a landlord or sublessor receives rental income covering more than one year, the total rental income is considered earned in the fiscal year it was received. However, the tax is calculated by dividing the income over the years it covers.

8. Rental of Business Assets
Income earned from renting out business assets, including equipment, machinery, and properties, is subject to tax under Schedule 'C' of the Proclamation.

businessGrowth.title: Directive on Issuance, Management, Use, Distribution, and Control of Receipts
businessGrowth.excerpt: The issuance, management, use, distribution, and control of receipts are governed by Directive No. 110/2008, which is based on the Federal Income Tax and Tax Administration Proclamations.
businessGrowth.fullContent:
The issuance, management, use, distribution, and control of receipts are governed by Directive No. 110/2008, which is based on the Federal Income Tax and Tax Administration Proclamations. According to these regulations, taxpayers classified under 'Category A' and 'Category B' are required to maintain accounting records, hold necessary information, and use legal receipts. Although taxpayers under 'Category C' are not legally obligated to maintain accounting records, they are encouraged to do so voluntarily. Therefore, taxpayers under 'Category A' and 'Category B' must ensure that their transactions are supported by receipts when conducting their business activities.

Information Required When Applying for a Receipt Printing Permit
According to Sub-Article 1 of Article 5 of Directive No. 110/2008 issued by the Ministry of Revenue, the following information must be submitted when applying for a receipt printing permit:
1. For organizations that have not yet started business operations or are not engaged in commercial activities but are in the investment process and are responsible for reduced income tax, the taxpayer identification number (TIN) and investment certificate must be provided to issue receipts for reduced tax purposes.
2. For taxpayers engaged in business activities, the taxpayer identification number (TIN), legal business registration, business license, and business name must be included on the issued receipts.
3. For agents responsible for reduced value-added tax (VAT), the taxpayer identification number (TIN) must be provided.
4. If a taxpayer requests their organization's logo to be included on the receipts, they must provide proof of registration of the logo from the Ethiopian Intellectual Property Office.

Detailed Information to Be Included on Receipts
According to Sub-Article 2 of Article 7 of the Directive, sales receipts must include at least the following basic information:
1. The full name, address, and registered business name of the supplier.
2. The supplier's taxpayer identification number (TIN), VAT number, and the date of tax registration.
3. The serial number of the receipt.
4. The full name, address, and taxpayer identification number (TIN) of the purchaser.
5. The type and quantity of goods delivered or services provided.
6. The amount of VAT or turnover tax applicable to the taxable transaction.
7. The total sales or transaction amount in words and figures.
8. The date the receipt was issued.
9. The name and signature of the employee who prepared and/or received the payment.
10. The name of the issuing organization, taxpayer identification number (TIN), date of issuance, and the certificate of competence of the issuer.
11. The letter number and date of authorization from the tax authority for the issuance of the receipt.

Responsibilities of Taxpayers Regarding Receipt Usage
According to Article 19 of the Directive, any taxpayer using receipts recognized by the tax authority must adhere to the following responsibilities:
- Do not use unauthorized or illegal receipts.
- Do not record different information on the original and duplicate copies of receipts.
- Ensure the actual sales price or amount is clearly stated on the receipt.
- Do not allow receipts issued to one taxpayer to be used by another.
- Do not conduct sales without issuing receipts.
- Do not refuse to issue receipts to customers who request them.
- Do not issue receipts with the same serial number for the same type of transaction.
- Do not use receipts issued before the tax authority granted the printing permit or after the permit has been revoked.
- Ensure all receipts contain the information specified in Article 7 of the Directive.
- Issue receipts with original and duplicate copies.
- Safely store receipts and retain receipts for transactions until the tax law specifies otherwise.
- Submit receipts when requested for audit or tax assessment.
- Display the receipt usage ledger in a visible location and ensure it contains accurate information.
- Issue manually printed receipts with the tax authority's approval if the sales recording device is unavailable.
- Immediately forward the second copy of the receipt to the accounting department along with supporting documents.
- Use receipts in sequential order and notify the tax office if receipts are used out of sequence.
- Maintain separate receipt sequences for different business locations or sectors.

Conclusion
According to the Proclamations, any taxpayer required to maintain accounting records must register the type and quantity of receipts with the tax authority before issuing them. Any person providing receipt printing services must verify that the receipts have been registered with the tax authority before printing them upon the taxpayer's request.

In general, any taxpayer required to maintain accounting records must issue receipts for their transactions and retain the necessary information.

In our city, notices such as 'Do not pay without a receipt!' are commonly seen in cafes, restaurants, beverage stores, and other businesses. These notices encourage the public to demand receipts. However, how many of us actually request or accept receipts when conducting transactions? How accountable are we in reporting transactions conducted without receipts to the relevant government authorities? Requesting and accepting receipts is not only our right but also a guarantee for our purchases. Conducting transactions without receipts creates unnecessary pressure on the legal business system and government revenue. Working together to prevent this is the only solution.
